story: Daniel Hannan last week claimed in a leaked WhatsApp message to have seen copies of Government files proposing EU nationals receive voting rights in the UK after Brexit.The Conservative MEP insisted the proposal would erode the idea of national citizenship &ndash arguing the British Government should treat EU citizens like any other overseas national..Speaking to LBC, Mr Hannan said: By virtue of owning citizenship you have certain rights and obligations, if you start automatically giving the franchise to people who are not within that citizenship then you might as well not have any concept of national citizenship at all.There&rsquoll be some who now say &lsquowell, we should have the right to vote anyway,&rsquo and I would say, in that case, make a commitment to the country and apply for UK citizenship. We&rsquod love to have you.                SNP politician openly admits existence of MEP PLOT to thwart Brexit                BREXIT LIVE: Labour could back Norway-style transition deal But if you&rsquore not prepared to do that then please stop telling us what rules we should run our elections by.Mr Hannan claimed the British Government is planning to adopt this proposal as part of a bizarre strategy to maintain close alignment with Brussels.He added: What we can&rsquot do is carry on as if we were still in the EU, which is the proposition that our negotiators have incredibly been pushing for in these Brexit talks.They said &lsquook, we will cease to be EU citizens but lets roll everything over as if we still were.&rsquo That seems to me an absolutely bizarre position for Britain to be asking for.Brexit news: Mr Hannan said EU nationals should not be allowed to vote in the UK (Image: CNBC&bull)Around 3.2 million EU citizens live in the UK, with 1.3 million Brits across the EU.In July the Brexit Select Committee in the House of Commons noted Brussels had refused to consider striking an agreement to maintain voting rights after withdrawal.A Government spokesman said: This is not within the scope of the Withdrawal Agreement.We have always been clear that the voting rights of both UK nationals living in the EU and EU nationals living in the UK should be considered together and that we're committed to doing bilateral deals to achieve this.The British Government has set aside a &pound9 million grant to help organisations working with vulnerable EU citizens who need extra support.Voluntary and community organisations will use the money to inform people about settled-status applications. It will also be used to help people complete their applications.

title: google earth us government ufo area 51 tonopah test range
story: Nick Pope, who used to work for the government&rsquos specialist UFO department, has said the discovery the search engine giant did not update images of the Tonopah Test Range for eight years is &ldquomurky.Using his insider background of how governments want to keep such facilities out of the public&rsquos knowledge, he has speculated the reason behind the blackout was because the American government kept top secret information and crashed UFOs.The search giant normally updates satellite images of every part of the continental United States every 60 days but no fresh photos of the Nevada facility appear on Google Earth between 2008 and 2016, it has emerged.This is despite most other military bases in the US being regularly logged.                'Secret Area 51 airline' flies special planes from Las Vegas                UFO PROOF: &lsquoStrange anomaly&rsquo spotted near Jupiter in shock NASA imagesMr Pope told the Sun Online that the base is close to the infamous Area 51, which is why he thinks the US government wanted Google&rsquos cameras to ignore the facility.He said: Because of its proximity to the infamous Area 51, this has understandably started all sorts of conspiracy theories in the UFO community.Could this super-secret location be where the US government hides crashed UFOs?&nbsp&ldquoOr is it where the next generation of stealth aircraft, drones and hypersonic weapons are developed and tested?Nick Pope believes Google and the US government blocked satellite images of the site (Image: Nick Pope)Either way the US government is hugely concerned - and understandably so.This is all quite murky. Either as a consequence of federal law, or through a 'gentleman's agreement', Google andor the third party providers from whom they obtain satellite imagery have ensured that the public won't see up-to-date images of the Tonopah Test Range.Along with drones flown by hobbyists, the easy availability of high-quality satellite imagery has caused immense problems for the military and the intelligence community.It's given people a window on a world that was previously closed to them.The Tonopah Test range is home to some of the US government&rsquos most secret projects (Image: UIG via Getty Images)Simply put, these technologies make it more difficult for the government to hide things.Having worked in the MoD for 21 years I well understand the need for secrecy, and indeed my final posting was to the Directorate of Defence Security.While I understand that people are naturally curious about what's going on at Tonopah, the problem with people's 'right to know' is that once information is in the public domain, it's seen by everyone: not just UFO researchers and aviation enthusiasts, but the Russians, the Chinese, the Iranians, the North Koreans, ISIS and all sorts of other non-state actors who may not have the best of intentions.The desert army barracks have long been the subject of mystery after it was reported the range has been used for secret government aerospace and weapons testing since the 1950s, including the development of the iconic stealth bombers.Aerial shot of the airbase in the Nevada desert (Image: Google)A spokesperson for Google denied any censorship of the base in a statement.The company said: &ldquoGoogle Earth didn&rsquot censor this area in Nevada.Our satellite imagery is licensed from third party providers which are commercially available and are not the property of Google.We update imagery by prioritising areas that are most popular with users while complying with local and federal laws.

title: angela merkel germany news hesse election cdu csu coalition
story: Germans head to the polls tomorrow (Sunday) in a local election in the western state of Hesse but recent polling suggests Ms Merkel&rsquos Christian Democratic Union (CDU) is on track for humiliating losses.And a poor performance by the CDU could spell the beginning of the end for the Chancellor&rsquos shaky coalition government - and potentially trigger another general election.Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, who was promoted to the CDU&rsquos general secretary, has been tipped as the likely successor to Ms Merkel once she leaves office.But Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer warned months of scandal and government quarrelling - which left the unstable coalition on the brink of collapse - have eroded voters&rsquo trust.                Hesse election polls 2018: When do polls open? When do polls close?                Angela Merkel news: Housing crisis could see END of German chancellorShe told The Times: &ldquoGermany is doing nicely, but the past few months of electioneering, the difficult process of forming a government and the wrangling within the government have all taken their toll.Ms Merkel&rsquos &lsquogrand coalition&rsquo government is made up of the CDU, its Bavarian sister party the CSU and the centre-left SPD - but all three have lost ground to opposition parties including the far-right AfD and the left wing Greens.The alliance has been plagued with infighting ever since the coalition reluctantly formed in March after months of failed talks.SPD members are now piling pressure on their own leaders to abandon the coalition and reinvent themselves.Angela Merkel's CDU party is on course for major losses in tomorrow's regional vote in Hesse (Image: EPA)Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer has been tipped as Ms Merkel's likely successor (Image:  IMAGES)The financial hub of Frankfurt is located in Hesse (Image:  IMAGES)                Fury as Germany must pay BILLIONS more to the EU after Brexit                 Italian MEP dismisses EU budget rejection with this brilliant pointBut speaking at a campaign event in Frankfurt earlier this week, Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer said this could have major consequences in Berlin.She said: If this government were to break apart now, it would lead to new elections.Opinion polls suggest a snap election would probably hurt the centre-right CDUCSU and SPD the most.Ms Merkel has been weakened by her 2015 decision to let more than a million migrants into Germany and her coalition government has lurched from crisis to crisis in recent months.Polling shows the Greens have overtaken Ms Merkel's coalition allies the SPD in Hesse (Image: AFP IMAGES)Recent polling shows her conservatives are still the biggest party. But their support has fallen to 26-27 percent, meaning a coalition with the SPD may no longer have sufficient support.Meanwhile, the environmentalist Greens, on 16-20 percent, have overtaken the SPD in most surveys.And the anti-immigration AfD remain strong with 15-17 percent.In tomorrow&rsquos ballot in Hesse, both Merkel's conservatives and the SPD are predicted to lose 10 percent of the vote compared to the last election in 2013.The AfD is poised to enter the state legislature for the first time with 12 percent support, an October 25 poll conducted for broadcaster ZDF showed.

title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. But it’s not just Harvey Weinstein and Hollywood.Over the past year, we’ve seen the High Court impose serious reporting restrictions on police arrests and a bid by Press-hating tycoon Max Mosley to wipe his fascist past out of history citing the ‘right to be forgotten’.It will be you, the public, who lose outthe rich and powerful stop us doing our job.GIVE us a date, Prime Minister.No, not for your departure. But for the end of the transition period.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond .If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.DOES John Bercow have no shame With every day he sits in the Speaker’s chair he discredits Parliament.His refusal to take allegations of bullying and harassment seriously is an embarrassment at the heart of our democracy.Parliament has a ready-made replacement for this rhino-hided oaf in Lindsay Hoyle — respected across the House.Bercow must go. Now.TURKISH supremo Recep Erdogan can spare us the holier than thou act on human rights.What happened to Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of the Saudis is disgraceful. But Erdogan’s record of political purges and locking up journalists is not far off.He has more in common with the regime in Riyadh than he’d like to think.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: man demand poppy removed outside home
story: The man, believed to be aged in his s, complained after the poppy was attached to a lamppost in Woodville, Derbyshire.They have been installed across the area by the Royal British Legion ahead of the th anniversary of the end of the war next month.South Derbyshire councillor Steve Taylor was confronted by the OAP while attaching the poppy.He told Derby : A man, in his s, comes outside and told us: You can take that away.We asked him: Do you know what it is for  It is for the th anniversary of the end of the war.He said: I couldnt give a damn. I wasnt born then. If you put it up then it will be gone by the morning.He and a fellow councillor decided the remove the poppy but have been left shocked by the mans reaction.And the pensioner has now been slammed by Mick Golder, chairman of the Swadlincote district branch of the Royal British Legion, who said the poppies are a symbol of the soldiers sacrice.He said: The poppies are there because of the sacrice of all the soldiers who unfortunately died.Our motto this year is thank you to everyone who made the sacrice, and for someone to have that attitude, to me personally, is disgusting but then again we live in a free country.It shouldnt matteryou werent born during the war. It is about sacrice.The British Legion describes the poppy as a “symbol of remembrance and hope” with many people wearing them on October  -  days before Remembrance Day.

title: man hiding 10 pound notes around uk
story: Matt Callanan has spent £, of his own money on a project he hopes will inspire people to do good deeds.So far film-maker Matt has left hundreds of envelopes scattered across Cardf and Dublin, and is planing to target cities in England and Scotland in the future.His project Tenner For Good involves putting a £ or € note in an envelope with two important rules.Number one: Dont spend the money on yourself. Number Two: Do some good with it.Matt stashes the cash in creative spots across the cities, including in bicycle wheels and on roadworks signs.He tries to place them in spots close to charity shops as a nudge to people who pick them up.In one instance he hid an envelope outside a childrens hospital under a bench.Matt told the Huffington Post: “[A man who works in the hospital] saw the envelope, went back in to the workplace, told them the story and they all started chipping in tenners.“He got to £ and he thought: what can we do for the kids They turned it into  Easter eggs and he went back dressed as a bunny and delivered all the eggs to the kids in the hospital.”He added: “I love that domino effect that you can create.“I think my favourite one that’s come out of it, there was this guy in Bristol and he didn’t find any of the tenners but he heard about it and wanted to do his own.“He brought this homeless guy into his house, listened to his story, gave him a cup of tea and on the way out gave him a couple of tenners, wished him well, and then the guy got back in touch with him a few weeks after that and said that he’d now got his benefits sorted, a job sorted and a house sorted.“And it was all because this guy Ben had given him his time and made him feel valued. That was just a lovely outcome.”Matt also teamed up with a local troop of Brownies to deliver thank you cards to doctors and nurses at a local hospital.He said: “And apparently all of these doctors and nurses ended up bursting into tears because it was just such a kind thing for these young girls to do for them.”

title: map reveals european holiday hotspots earthquakes volcanoes seismic activity
story: But some regions - many considered among some of the best holiday destinations in the world - are at much greater risk of deadly events linked to seismic activity.Just last night, a huge . magnitude earthquake tore through the Greek holiday isle of Zante, ripping up roads and buildings filled with holidaymakers.British Geological Survey seismologist Margarita Segou told The Sun Online: Greece and Italy have the largest seismic hazard, as we say, which means that earthquakes are more frequent there.However, we have cases of big earthquakes in other countries in historical times, such as Spain.The reason why Greece and Italy are the most seismic areas in Europe is they are areas where seismic plates are forming. The African plate is subdacting, going under, and the European plate we say itsabout cm a year.So all this middle and southern Mediterranean is a very active zone, so it has produced many earthquakes in historical times and in the present.We have stories collected from historical times from a large earthquake magnitude . offshore near Crete in AD which produced a tsunami and reached even Egypt.We have another in AD near Sicily, which devastated some cities in Sicily and caused a tsunami.Large scale earthquakes will continue to go ahead in Italy and Greece. But not only big earthquakes are associated with big risk.She cited last years . magnitude earthquake which struck central Italy as one example of a moderate tremor that can cause carnage.This hit on January  a few kilometres northwest of the town of LAquila, killing  people and laying waste to several ancient towns.She added: Risk comes even from moderate earthquakes, they tend to happen every five years in these countries. They are more frequent than large ones.Last year scientists said they expected an increase in earthquakes due to a tiny decrease in the speed of the planets rotation.A report presented at the Geological Society of America argued that five periods of intense seismic activity throughout history have followed periods of when the Earths rotation slowed.However, Segou did not believe the frequency of the tremors hitting Europe was increasing.Associate Professor of Earthquake Science in the School of Earth Sciences at the University of Melbourne, Mark Quigley has previously told news.au central Italy is experiencing crustal extension.He says: Eastern central Italy is moving to the NE relative to Rome.As a result, this region experiences normal faulting earthquakes as the land is torn apart. The fault systems are short and structurally complex, so the earthquakes are not overly large by global standards.But because the earthquakes are shallow and structurally complex, and because many of the local towns and cities contain vulnerable buildings, strong shaking from these earthquakes has the potential to inflict major damage and loss of le in urban areas.Some  per cent occur around the rim of the Pacic Ocean.The plates - giant rock slabs that make up the Earths upper layer - are always slowly moving.They often collide and slide against each other, according to National Geographic.This impact can be unnoticeable on the surface but can cause immense stress between the plates.When this stress is released, it causes massive vibrations, called seismic waves, often hundreds of miles through the rock to the surface.There are fears that there is a big one on the way after a flurry of volcanic activity in the Pacics Ring of Fire.A study from Calornia says that the cluster of tremors around the planets so-called Ring of Fire- a horseshoe-shaped geological disaster zone - could indicate the big one is due to hit.The research, published in the journal Science Advances, involved analysis of  major earthquakes around the Pacic Ring of Fire between  and .Europe also has a number of volcanoes - some dormant, others active - which have in the past caused catastrophic events and huge loss of le.Among these is Mount Etna, on Sicily, which was first recorded erupting in BC, and has exploded around  times since.This last occurred in  when a BBC crew were pelted with boiling rocks and steam as they filmed the mountainside.Many in Europe also remember the  eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull, in Iceland, which triggered huge air travel disruptions across western and northern Europe.Last year, researchers at the University of Leeds revealed the findings of a study which determined such ash cloud eruptions could occur once every  years.Co-author Dr Graeme Swindles said: In , when Eyjafjallajökull erupted, people were really shocked – it seemed to come completely out of the blue, but the eruption of Grímsvötn, the following year, was an extraordinary coincidence.Although it is possible that ash clouds can occur on an annual basis, the averageinterval for the last , years is around  years.The last time volcanic ash clouds affected northern Europe before the recent event was in ,  years ago – but aviation was much less intense at that time and it simply didnt have the same sort of impact.Our research shows that, over thousands of years, these sorts of incidents are not that rare – but people wondering how likely it is that the  chaos will be repeated in the next few years can feel somewhat reassured.Just this year alone the world has witnessed destructive eruptions in Hawaii, Bali and Guatemala.However, Clive Oppenheimer, professor of volcanology at the University of Cambridge, says there has not been an increase in volcanic activity.He told The : There have been quite a few eruptions in the news lately, so people question whether there’s an increase in rates of volcanism that we’re seeing just now, and this isn’t really the case.Eruptions are happening all the time - some make the news headlines and others don’t.If we look at the statistics back in time, the main thing we see is a reporting bias. There are not many eruptions during World War Two, for example, when people had other things to really worry about.So of course things will flare up in one place or another place and then it will be very much how those eruptions affect people and whereabouts in the world - whether that then becomes newsworthy.

title: sewage drinking water thames bosses
story: Thames Water said today the UKs capital will lose £ million a daydramatic measures arent put in place to save the citys water supply.The population of London is set to rise by two million people in the next  years which could lead to a million litre daily shortfall of water, made worse by climate change reducing natural resources.So Thames Water plans to open a reuse plant at the Deephams Sewage Treatment Works in North East London which will turn sewage into water clean enough to drink - a UK first, the Evening Standard reports.But the plant is not currently planned for everyday use - its intended for times of projected or actual drought.Discussions with the Environment Agency are ongoing about the viability of this plan.After plans to build a new £.billion reservoir in Oxfordshire were rejected by the government in , the plan is being revived by Thames Water.It is intended for water to be shipped down the Thames along the Oxford Canal to ensure taps keep flowing.The reservoir near Abingdon would play a vital role in supplying water to the South East.It will be complete by ,the government approves it.Thames Water also owns the UKs only desalination plant in Beckton, East London, which turns sea water into million litres of drinking water a day during drought.The company has a water resources management plan for the next  years which has budgeted £.billion until .A spokesperson said Thames Water is pledging to reduce leakage from its ,-mile network of pipes.He added: “More needs to be done to protect Londoners from the risk of severe drought.“Restrictions on water use in London alone could cost more than £million a day.”The reuse plant will put million litres of water a day back into the system by passing treated sewage through a desalination membrane to clean it.Its then mixed with reservoir water, treated again and pumped into the network.The spokesperson added: “We wouldn’t consider reusewe didn’t think the water would be good enough.”

title: mcdonalds human poo london newham

story: The stoppage came just  days after the gas extraction restarted following a seven-year pause.The tremor was classed as a red event under the fracking regulation traffic-light scheme because it exceeded . magnitude.Sixteen tremors have been recorded in the area by the ­British Geological Survey since October , but none this large.A spokesman for the BGS said the quake was “right on top” of the site, adding: “It’s been caused by the fracking.”Under the rules, work must stop for  hours while monitoring is carried out.Cuadrilla, the energy company fracking at the Preston New Road site in Little Plumpton, Lancs, described the quake as “micro seismic”.It added: “Events such as these result in tiny movements that are way below anything that would be felt at surface, much less cause any harm or damage.”Workers were hydraulically fracturing shale rock when the tremor was recorded near a well km underground at .am.The controversial work had started again after an environmental campaigner failed to block it at the High Court. It is the first fracking to take place in the UK since , when Cuadrilla’s work near Blackpool was halted following two quakes.Friends of the Earth’s Rose Dickinson said: “When is the Government going to realise fracking is the wrong choice for Lancashire, the UK and our global climate ”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles wanted call off wedding diana
story: In a new biography, he describes how he wanted to break off his engagement to the aristocrats daughter when I discovered how awful the prospects were.In the explosive book, serialised in the stare back at him blankly.The more he saw of his volatile fiancee, the more Charles knew in his heart that he’d made a terrible mistake.That the Prince went ahead with the marriage, despite his firm conviction that it was a mistake, is something he deeply regrets to this day.According to Jobson, Charles wants to challenge pernicious lies about him which he believes were orchestrated by Diana.Charles doubts over the wedding are bound to shock some people.Until now, its been reported that it was Diana who wanted to call off the wedding.Earlier this month the Sun Online told how, just hours before marrying Charles, Diana suffered a bulimic attack.The revelations have been made in Charles, The Misunderstood Prince, written by Sally Bedell Smith, where she details the hours leading up to the big day.Diana’s struggles with bulimia are now common knowledge, with the late princess opening up about her eating disorder in recorded tapes.The book says: “On her wedding eve at Clarence House, Diana could hear the spectacular fireworks celebrations in Hyde Park.“Unknown to even her sister Jane, who stayed with her, Diana had a bulimic attack and was sick as a parrot.The same book also tells how Charles was having second thoughts, which he relayed to his valet, Stephen Barry.The book says: “He did not share the exuberance on display outside the Palace.“Rather, he was in a contemplative mood.“As he listened to the choruses of Rule Britannia, Charles found himself weeping. Stephen Barry asked what was wrong.“Stephen,” he said, “Is it possible to love two women at the same time ”Despite both their fears, the pair tied the knot in front of a congregation of , people, with some  million tuning in to watch the event on TV.But Camilla Parker-Bowles would be a thorn in Diana’s side throughout her marriage to Prince Charles.She saw her as the other woman, and it was later revealed the pair had a relationship while Princes Charles was still married.In her explosive interview with Martin Bashir, Princess Diana infamously said there were “three people” in her marriage.Prince Charles later went on to marry Camilla in , but she refrains from using the title the Princess of Wales out of respect for Diana.

title: couples get wed in mcdonalds budget plans
story: Chancellor Philip Hammond will announce a review of “outdated” marriage ceremony laws that require venues to abide by strict and costly rules to stage weddings.The overhaul of rules would also allow open air weddings.The move is designed to slash the cost of getting married.Currently the average cost of venue hire for a wedding in the UK is £, - a signicant chunk of the average total wedding cost of between £, and £,.Current red tape required to become a wedding venue includes needing to dedicate a specic room where the ceremony takes place - as well as needing to be part of a building rather than outside, evenit’s under a marquee.Wedding licence holders must also make sure that no food or alcoholic drinks are sold or consumed in the specic marriage ceremony area one hour before and during the proceedings.Treasury officials said this burdensome red tape deters small business owners from seeking to get a licence.Relaxing restrictions would make it cheaper and simpler for couples to get married - and would encourage more to tie the knot, they said.Meanwhile a bid to extend civil partnerships to mixed-sex couples hit a snag after the Government refused to back a Tory MP’s draft legislation - despite it clearing the House of Commons yesterday.Women and Equalities Minister Penny Mordaunt said there were a “number of questions” about making the changes after a Private Members Bill brought forward by ex-minister Tim Loughton was approved in the Commons.The bill seeks to open civil partnerships to opposite-sex couples for the first time.Ms Mordaunt said the Government would instead introduce its own legislation to bring about the necessary changes.But MPs would only get to see the plans next year at the earliest.This is despite Theresa May announcing last month that straight couples will get the same opportunity to enter a civil partnership as same sex couples.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the queen abdicate prince charles
story: Her Majesty will step down at the age of  letting her son take over as Prince Regent while she is still alive.Queen Elizabeth, at , is the oldest and longest-serving monarch following her coronation in .A new book by royal correspondent Robert Jobson has predicted her early abdication, reports Mail Online.Clarence House, the official residence of the Prince of Wales, has made no comment.But bookies are offering odds as short as   that the Queen will step down.Robert has said in the past: I understand the Queen has given the matter considerable thought and believes that,she is still alive at , she will seriously consider passing the reign to Charles.“Her Majesty is mindful of her age and wants to make sure when the time comes, the transition of the Crown is seamless.”The new biography also claims Charles was desperate to call off his wedding to Diana but feared backlash from the royal family.Charles at Seventy: Thoughts, Hopes and Dreams, marks Charles th birthday and is available in November.Jobson says that Charles knew he and Diana were not suited within just a handful of meetings.Last year, her husband Prince Philip officially retired from public duties at the age of .Prince Charles has gradually been filling in for his mother.He ha represented the head of state on foreign trips during her Diamond Jubilee year to Australia and New Zealand.

story: Susanne Willdig was ordered to pay the charge because the machine didnt accept cards and paying was the only way to lt the barrier.Ms Willdig claims she had only spent five minutes in the car park, and was expecting to pay a £ fee.She told Bristol Live she didnt have  £ coins, or  £ coins, on her, and so a queue of cars built up behind her.But after failing to reach anyone on the toll booth assistance button, she managed to find a local police officer.She said: He radioed around, talked to their central office and eventually they let me out.He reckoned the machine simply didn’t like my number plate, which is a standard plate so I’m not sure why - that’s never happened before.When I finally got out, I saw a huge tailback queue which I think was caused by me being stuck there, because I was blocking one barrier, one was out of order already, so there was only one ing barrier for the whole express car park.A spokesperson for Bristol Airport said the issue was caused by the machines number plate recognition software maling.

title: baby girl premature wales cardiff hand
story: Baby Hallie Sofia Dury was born at the University Hospital of Wales, Cardf, on Tuesday, weighing just g.Mum Robyn Bryant is overwhelmed with joy as medics repeatedly told her Hallie could die from  weeks.She said: Everyone was blown away by her. Shes tiny - around the same size as my iPhone.I cant even describe how happy I am. I wasnt prepared to hear her crying and fighting, so when she did - I was so overwhelemed.Robyn Bryant said her pregnancy became very stressful from  weeks as doctors told her and partner James Dury that Hallie could pass away at anytime.At  weeks, medics said Hallie was not viable, meaning she would not be able to survive outside of the uterus.Recalling the delivery, Robyn said: There were loads of doctors and nurses, waiting to take her, in case she wasnt breathing.But, she proved everyone wrong - she came out screaming, crying, fighting and breathing on her own.The placenta was the size of the palm of my hand and was grey and gritty - there was no bloody flow there.Hallie is now being kept in a high-dependency unit at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf, while Robyn and James are staying in nearby accommodation provided by the Ronald McDonald charity.Robyn is now telling her story in a bid to raise awareness of premature births and to reassure women who may be going through similar experiences.I was speaking to other mams who had been through similar experiences and it really helped me.There was so much support there. Everyone had time for me.I want to be able to give that back now, andanyone wants to message me or talk then I would be up for that.

title: primary school teacher investigated for wearing blackface napolean dynamite costume to halloween party
story: Megan Luloff, , from Iowa, posed for photographs wearing dark body paint on her face, arms and feet.She was part of a group dressed as characters from the  movie Napoleon Dynamite, and also wore a wig similar to the hairstyle of African-American character LaFawnduh.Luloff teaches at Walcott Elementary School, and faces calls for her firing from the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People .NAACP president for Iowa and Nebraksa Betty Andrews said she was shocked when her organisation received a copy of the photo.Someone in Luloff’s group should have realised her “serious lapse in judgement” and said something to the teacher, Andrews said.“It’s incredibly concerning that she was with a group of people who didn’t say, ‘Hey, this is a problem … Clearly someone did find it offensive though because that is why we got the photo in the first place.”“Being a teacher, this is a serious lapse in judgement and her presence in a classroom could be detrimental to any student she teaches, particularly African-American students.”“I would definitely not want her teaching my children. This makes me wonder what’s in the water, so to speak. What are we teaching in Davenport for this woman to think that this would be OK ”Luloff, whose photo no longer appeared on the school’s website as of Thursday, did not respond to a message seeking comment.An investigation into the photo is now underway, district officials told the Quad-City Times.District spokeswoman Dawn Saul told The Post that two complaints had been received in connection to the photo and that the district became aware of the incident on Monday.Saul could not indicate whether Luloff was teaching at the school on Thursday and the teacher has been worked at the district for about  years.Superintendent Art Tate said in an email to the Quad-City Times: “The wearing of blackface is never appropriate in any circumstance by any person.“The issue is under investigation by the district.”The Davenport School District is under state supervision because a disproportionate number of minority students have been identied for special education programs and subjected to disciplinary actions, according to the Quad-City Times.“The district was very recently made aware of these images of a district employee at a non-school related event, and an internal investigation is currently ongoing,” district officials said in a statement.“The board does not condone the insensitivity these images depict and is very disappointed something like this is now connected to our school community.”

title: british summer time end sunday october extra sleep
story: To make better use of daylight, our clocks will go backwards on the last Sunday in October.Tomorrow Greenwich Mean Timewill resume, in line with the phrase spring forward in spring, fall back in fall.This means that we will all get an extra hour of sleep but at the cost of darker evenings.William Willett created Daylight Saving Time in  in a bid to stop people wasting valuable hours of light in the summer months.By setting the clocks back in winter, Brits get an earlier sunrise and earlier sunset.In summer the sun rises and sets one hour later than it would without daylight saving.The barmy EU directive could spell the end of the autumn lie-in on October .Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said millions believe that in future, summer time should be year-round, and thats what will happen.The Commissions proposal requires support from the  national governments and MEPs to become law.The move would mean EU countries having to choose between adopting a permanent summer or winter time - meaning Belfast would have to decide whether to align its clocks with London or Dublin.

title: budget 2018 philip hammond interest free cash loans
story: Philip Hammond will extend a helping hand to save poorest people from the clutches of payday loan sharks.He wants banks to forge a new partnership with debt charities to support low-income households pay for unexpected costs.The action will be announced in Mondays Budget in a package of measures to tackle problem debt.It follows widespread concern over payday lenders such as Quickquid who offer short-term cash fixes at sky-high rates.Mr Hammond believes he can devise an affordable alternative to high-cost credit which has left hundreds of thousands in a spiral of debt.He aims to copy the “Good Shepherd” scheme in Australia which helped four in five people to climb out of the red.In a further move, the six-week “breathing space” to protect borrowers from creditor action will be increased to  days – giving them more time to get their finances back on tract.The Chancellor is also expected to announce a £ million challenge fund to find a solution to make it easier and more attractive to borrow from affordable lenders.A Treasury source said: “You can expect a number of measures as part of a long-term plan to tackle problem debt and ensure all families have access to the financial services they need.”Payday loans are more damaging to our health than any other form of credit, according to a recent report.They are widely seen as the worst type of credit, ahead of unauthorised overdrafts.Nearly , complaints were made about payday load between April and June this year – a  per cent rise on the , filed to the Financial Ombudsman Service in the same period the previous year.Last night the government action was welcomed by Money saving expert Martin Lewis.He said: “It’s good news. We’ve been at the mercy of payday lenders and exorbitant interest rates for far too long.”But Labour dismissed the plan as a “farcical gimmick”.Shadow chancellor John McDonnell said: “It will do nothing to prevent more people falling into debt traps, since these measures do not cap excessive interest rates and other fees.”Communities Sec James Brokenshire convinced the Chancellor to allocate the funds as part of the £billion promised to the NHS.Health Sec Matt Hancock has long earmarked social care for dramatic improvement.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. A combination of austerity and incompetence has left the prison and probation services on their knees and the latest statistics should be a matter of national shame. title: couples horror builder leaves house
story: NewsCouples horror as builder leaves their house looking like a bomb site - and takes keys as ransomThe first-time buyers, who have a child, are furious with the tradesman who left the job unfinished and the house in a messShareCommentsByAnna Riley:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsThe bath will have to be replaced after the mess that was left "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pair of first-time buyers have been left devastated after a builder left their house like a bomb site. The couple, from Hull, booked him to tile their bathroom but he left the job unfinished and the property in a complete mess, with rubbish piled in every room. But they say the man still wants to be paid in full - and has taken their house keys for ransom until they do so. The houseowner and mum-of-one, aged , who asked not to be named, booked the tradesman online. We asked around for recommendations but nobody knew of anyone who could do the work, she told Hull Live .  We found a guy that said he could do the work at a decent price, so we agreed to take him on. The first night on the Monday we checked into the house to see how he was getting on, as we arent living in it at the moment until it is all done up, and it all looked fine. We didnt have time to call in on Tuesday, but on the Wednesday when the work was meant to be finished, we walked in to an absolute bomb site. She says the tiler left a mess in nearly every room of the house, and thinks what he has done in the home is completely disrespectful. Grout was all up the walls, the tiles were wonky, the mosaic doesnt go all the way up the ceiling and the floor tiles are ruined, she said. Were also going to need a new bath as he let grout fall in there and took the protective peel off it, and now all the grout has hardened and scratched it. He trashed the bedroom that will be my sons by leaving all the rubbish in there and he left the kitchen in a state with grout splattered all up the walls where he mixed it for the tiles - why he didnt go outside to mix it I just cant understand. He also left mucky hand prints on the fridge and had unplugged it after helping himself to all our drinks. The carpets in the rooms were also left a mess where he had walked about and left tile cuttings.  The tiler still quoted pound for the work, but the homeowners say they are not paying it and estimate it may now cost another pound to put right his work and replace items he ruined. We offered him pound for the work so that he would give us his house keys back, which we though was a fair contribution, but hes demanded more money off us and has said the bathroom has been left like it is because the walls are poor. His we has called us screaming down the phone to demand money from us, and hes emotionally blackmailed us by saying his daughter is giving him money from her piggy bank as we arent paying him. We just cant afford it, though, when we are going to have to pay out so much to fix what hes done. The couple say the situation has taken its toll and they are now worried about employing another tiler. My partner is absolutely livid about it all and Im really annoyed, she said.

title: homeowner who secretly built four
story: NewsHomeowner who secretly built four-bed bungalow hidden behind trees is ordered to tear it downThe council said the order serves as a warning to anyone who decides to ignore the planning processShareCommentsByJanet HughesGrace Witherden:,  OCT NewsMr Turley has been told to demolish his four-bedroom bungalow"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA builder has been ordered to tear down his four-bedroom bungalow after he illegally built it behind trees and bushes without planning permission. Steve Turley was served an enforcement notice by the Forest of Dean District Council last year which demanded he bulldoze his makesht house, extended outbuildings and a static caravan. Mr Turley appealed the ruling, but a planning inspector has now backed the council. He began construction of the property in near Lydney, Gloucestershire, after he sold his six-bedroom house for pound, three years ago, reports Gloucestershire Live. The house was put on the market with no onward chain and sold, without the land which is on the opposite side of the road.  A complaint was made to the council which informed them that members of his family were living on the land in an unauthorised bedroom bungalow and caravan hidden behind high walls and hedges. Mr Turley argued it was permitted development but the council officials said the location was unsustainable. A council spokesperson said: Mr Steve Turley constructed a dwelling on the site and extended outbuildings without planning permission.  Forest of Dean District Council served an enforcement notice in December , instructing him to restore the site to its original condition before the planning breach took place, cease the use of the land for residential purposes, remove the static caravan, portable building and demolish the dwelling and concrete hard standings at the site. Mr Turley appealed the notice. While the inspector acknowledged that the instruction to remove the hard standings was excessive, he upheld the Councils other requests for demolition. Philip Burford, the chairman of the planning committee, said: This decision serves as a warning to anyone who decides to ignore the planning process and the message is clear: dont spend a considerable amount of money and time on a building project in the knowledge that it does not have planning permission.

title: meteorite explodes night sky after
story: NewsMeteorite EXPLODES in night sky after Earth passes through stream of debris from Halleys cometLandscape astro-photographer Nick Jackson said he was just in the right place at the right timeShareCommentsByGrace Witherden:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video meteor-lights-up-night-sky-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA once-in-a-letime moment was witnessed above a castle as a meteor exploded and disintegrated into the night sky. The stunning images were caught on camera at Clun Castle, Shropshire, during an Orionid meteor shower on October . Orionid meteors occur every autumn when the Earth is passing through the stream of debris left by Halley’s Comet. The video was captured by landscape astro-photographer Nick Jackson who had gone to the castle to shoot the th century building in front of the night sky. He was hoping to make a star trial but halfway through the shoot he saw the meteor fly across the sky.  The -year-old said: I immediately thought, I hope that was caught in the frame. Its very unusual to see a meteor that big. Because I was shooting the star trail, I couldnt check the footage immediately. It was a sheer stroke of luck that I just happened to be shooting the series of images when it happened.  With things like that, youve got to be in the right place at the right time. Mr Jackson, from Ludlow, combined the images to create four seconds of footage. As a circular cloud of debris disperses into the starlit sky, two more meteors can be seen streaking into video from dferent directions. He said: Its very unusual to see a meteor that big. Because I was shooting the star trail, I couldnt check the footage immediately.  There are very few images out there that have captured this before. I posted it on Facebook on some astronomy groups and it just blew up over the weekend. People were saying, Youre a lucky guy, thats a once-in-a-letime thing’.  The reason we photographers go out in the middle of the night and stand there in the freezing cold is because were obsessed with the beauty of the night sky, its peace and calm. And when you see something like that, its just awe-inspiring.

title: summer 76 like long holiday
story: NewsopinionThe summer of   That was like a long holiday in a hot tub with Charlies Angels compared to thisPre-Thatcherite days of sunshine were actually incredibly dferent from the present – as we had a sense of community and ­fairness back thenShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  JUL NewsopinionThose comparing the current UK climate with the one shown here at Birmingham lido in  are forgetting how dferent times were then "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheres been a lot of talk about how this summer is just like the one we had in . Something to do with the sun, shyapparently. And how it refuses to go away, leaving us red, sweaty and worried about the dog. It’s given commentators a chance to contrast then and now, with some right-wingers declaring that le was much worse in those dark, pre-Thatcherite days when it took the GPO weeks to install a phone, inflation was % and unions held the country to ransom. Which is a load of Space Hopper-sized balls. As the New Economics Foundation concluded  years ago,  was the best year on record for equality of incomes and quality of le. We had a sense of community and shyfairness back then. We invested in public services so you could get seen quickly at hospitals and borrow books from libraries, there were untouched parks and school playing fields and councils filled in potholes. University education was free, with maintenance grants paid to poorer kids, houses were affordable for first-time buyers, and most families could get a council home to rent. People worked fewer hours in more secure jobs and were offered decent pensions.  There was Taxi Driver on at the pictures, Rising Damp on the telly, every kind of music from Abba to The Sex Pistols and it cost as little as p to watch the best football teams. I’m not saying everything was hunky-dory. Homophobia, racism, sexism and police corruption went unchecked, and due to under-investment, poor industrial relations and the after-effects of the global oil crisis, the economy was slumping. But compared with today,  seems like a long holiday spent in a hot tub with Charlie’s Angels. In , we are a bitterly ided nation with a directionless government talking about stockpiling food and shymedicines in case a no-deal Brexit pushes us off a clf. A Resolution Foundation report has just warned that eight million “just about managing” families are no better off today than in  due to income stagnation marking the largest rise in poverty since Thatcher’s era. We work longer hours in far less secure jobs, the NHS is in crisis, there are hordes of homeless on the streets, childhood obesity and diabetes are at epidemic levels, students are smothered in debt, the young can’t afford to leave their parents and underfunded police have given up chasing many criminals. Worst of all, greed at the top has gone off the scale and wealth disparities have never been more glaring. In , the average British CEO earned  times what his average employee did. Today the average FTSE chief executive earns almost  times more than a worker on the National Living Wage.

story: NewsMan who found well under his living room  years ago keeps digging in bid to find something Colin and Vanessa Steer first noticed a dip in their living room floor when they first moved into the Plymouth home in the sShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsColin Steer discovered the hole in the s "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Colin and Vanessa Steer moved into their dream terrace house in the s the noticed a slight dip in the living room floor. So when Colin was replacing the floor joists in the Plymouth home, he decided to have a little dig down to see what was going on and was amazed to discover a well. The couple had three young children at the time, so decided to cover it up so it was safer for them. But after Colin retired from his job in the civil service, he decided it was time to have another little look. He soon found the hole was a lot bigger than he first thought, and with the help of a friend has now managed to dig down ft.  He said: The hole was full of earth, but with the help of a neighbour, we have managed to get about ft deep. I always wanted to dig it out to seeI could find a pot of gold at the bottom, so when I retired thats what I did. I was quite surprised really, I would have preferred it to be in the garden where I could have got at it a little easier. Using a ladder and a bucket on a pulley system, it took them around six months to get to the depth it is at now.  Colin said: We think its a bottle well. Its  inches wide now and could go down another -ft. I thought Id found a sword around ft down - it was a wooden thing that must have had a leather sheath on it as you can see stitch holes. Thats why I want to get to the bottom. Who knows whats down there. We have no idea when it was built. There could have been a couple of cottages here or it could have served a farm. Id like to find something down the bottom, something to give me an age. I wish I had a Tardis to go back in time and see what was here.
